1.17.text:
- It's fair to say
that North Korea

2.50.text: is one of the most isolated,

7.44.text:
Part of the reason that
it is so misunderstood

11.88.text: and nothing is know about it,

13.08.text:
is there's been
very few photographs

14.41.text: that have ever been taken there.

24.16.text:
came up with the idea to open
an office in North Korea,

27.23.text:
and I begged them to let me
be the Pyongyang photographer

32.93.text:
I went there, and that
meant that I was the first

36.14.text:
have regular access
to the country.

39.24.text:
I've made about 40 almost
50 trips to North Korea.

42.58.text:
It was a very difficult
place to work,

45.65.text:
You can't just
move around freely

48.65.text:
A guide goes with
you everywhere,

50.52.text:
and they are sort of half
facilitator, half babysitter.

54.99.text: They didn't censor what I did,

56.69.text:
they didn't put their
hand in front of my lens.

59.23.text:
But they did have a
very different idea

61.23.text:
of how I should be
portraying their country.

65.67.text:
In fact they had a
very different idea

69.27.text:
The word propagandist is not
a dirty word in North Korea,

72.07.text:
it's what they do at
their news agency.

74.67.text:
But I went there, I
think, with an open mind,

77.84.text:
and a free mind,
and a point of view.

80.75.text: This is their version of NASA.

85.22.text:
On the week that
the North Koreans

87.02.text:
were going to test
fire a missile,

90.99.text:
the whole world
was condemning them

93.39.text:
a test of a
nuclear-capable rocket.

96.13.text:
The North Koreans
were saying no,

97.36.text:
this is a rocket we're
gonna put into space

103.27.text: so that I could photograph it.

105.74.text:
This is the best
example what my job was

107.71.text: while I was in North Korea.

111.21.text:
trying to decide what was
real and what was not real.

113.61.text:
And I did that
through photography.

121.42.text:
I wasn't the (laughing)
senior most American diplomat

129.33.text:
Here he is smoking
a cigar in the gym,

131.03.text:
helping pick the
national basketball team.

136.67.text:
I covered the spectacles
and the propaganda.

139.91.text:
This was a mass
synchronized swimming event

142.64.text: for the birthday of the leader.

144.28.text:
They were swimming
or dancing to a song

145.78.text:
called We Will Defend Kim
Jong-un With our Very Lives.

149.52.text:
And this is the national
football stadium.

152.59.text:
They hold this thing that
they call mass games.

155.22.text: It's like a wonder of the world.

159.06.text:
holding these books
with colored pages,

162.50.text:
and they flip them, and they
create these mass mosaics.

166.97.text: but you with a long enough lens,

168.47.text:
you can see that they're
actually human pixels,

170.84.text:
little faces peeking over
the tops of the books.

178.04.text:
Sometimes you just
have to photograph

179.61.text:
whatever's right
in front of you.

182.58.text:
You don't really
have to try so hard.

184.58.text:
That's kind the way I
worked everywhere I went.

186.59.text:
You know if they took me to
a patriotic flag factory,

189.12.text: or a school for performing arts,

192.22.text:
I just pretty much photographed
what was in front of me.

194.16.text:
I thought it was
revealing to show

195.53.text:
how the Koreans wanted
to present themselves

199.63.text:
And over time I got
further and further away

201.27.text:
from the spectacles and
away from the capital

203.30.text:
and out into places that
really no other foreigners

207.17.text:
And certainly very few
photographers had ever seen.

210.14.text:
And maybe it was even
more important to me,

212.98.text:
that I found my way
into people's homes

218.18.text:
who's a secretary at the
Korean Central News Agency,

220.02.text:
with her little
aquarium full of fish.

222.79.text:
And I could look
into people's eyes

224.32.text:
and feel like I actually could
make a connection to Koreans.

227.63.text:
I traveled with then Secretary
of State Madeleine Albright.

230.66.text:
As she met with then
leader Kim Jong-il.

233.37.text:
We stood in this Wizard
of Oz looking palace,

238.57.text:
and we were all alone waiting
for him to come in the room.

240.64.text: And she looked at me and said,

241.87.text:
"what should I do,
where should I stand?"

244.14.text: And I said, "I have no idea."

246.51.text: We stood on these big flowers,

247.68.text:
and then the door
opened and he walked in.

250.58.text:
And it was like
I'd only seen this

252.52.text:
kind of fantasy
in a movie before.

255.55.text:
And it was like he just
stepped out of the screen

259.69.text:
It was the first time
that I understood

261.13.text: how I connected to that country

264.23.text:
and how surreal and how I
connected as a photographer.

267.33.text:
But also it was the
first time I realized

268.60.text:
how important the work
that I could do there,

271.00.text:
if I could only invest my
time and commit to the place.

274.17.text:
Now it wasn't easy
at the beginning.

277.84.text:
And on my first trip
with Madeleine Albright,

279.21.text: when I came out of the airport,

280.91.text:
they drew the
drapes on the bus.

282.82.text:
They put black plastic over
the windows of my hotel.

287.02.text:
I felt like there was
nothing real out there,

289.09.text: it was all just a facade.

291.56.text:
But over the years,
through photography,

293.59.text:
I could peek around out to the
other side of those curtains.

297.60.text:
And I came to understand
that there was real life

303.97.text:
I tried to take everybody
else on that same journey.

306.61.text:
There was no better
place than North Korea

307.97.text:
to test the power
of photography.

314.21.text:
in ways that writing or
any other medium can't.

317.75.text:
So when this pale pink
curtain comes down,

320.65.text:
just covers the eyes of
the people in Pyongyang,

324.79.text:
I can say something that
I couldn't say in words.

327.83.text:
And photography has multiple
meanings and interpretations.

331.73.text:
This is kinda how
I survived there,

335.90.text:
This was a vocational
school for children

338.04.text: to teach them how to be farmers.

340.94.text:
and they were very
proud to show me

344.71.text:
Of course for people outside,
they see it differently.

347.28.text:
We see their care and their
love for their children,

349.25.text:
but to us this is
a practice tractor

351.48.text:
with this sort of DOS-level
computer terminal on top.

357.49.text:
We had a lot of
very tough arguments

359.26.text:
about why did you
take that photograph?

362.29.text:
We saw that picture, that
doesn't make us look good.

365.23.text:
But I could always fall
back on photography.

367.53.text: I could hold it up and say,

368.80.text: this is what I saw, I was there.

374.11.text:
I used many different
camera formats,

377.54.text:
but because of the cat and
mouse game I had to play

382.68.text:
This is an old-fashioned
camera they don't make anymore,

384.65.text:
a Hasselblad XPan,
a film camera.

387.09.text: I wore it around my neck.

389.35.text:
I had a cable release so I
could just talk and smile

393.46.text:
And I had a little carpenter's
level in the flash mount

397.46.text:
so I could make sure that my
horizons were all straight.

400.97.text:
And when I picked up my big
fancy National Geographic camera

403.90.text:
sometimes people were
a bit intimidated,

406.01.text:
and the guides certainly watched
me a little more closely.

409.08.text: But when I used this one,

410.54.text:
they would say aw that's just
David's old-tiny camera.

412.68.text:
And I did the same
with my mobile phone.

416.02.text:
I took my mobile phone
into North Korea.

418.12.text:
Everybody by now is a
mobile phone photographer.

420.92.text:
We all are, even
the North Koreans

422.42.text:
take pictures with their
phones, believe it or not.

425.72.text:
And I was able to do
things that I couldn't do

430.83.text:
to see me with a mobile
phone taking pictures.

433.13.text:
And I would also
stop and photograph

435.74.text:
things that I wouldn't
normally notice

437.14.text:
if I was working as
a photojournalist.

438.97.text:
Things that you rush
past on your way

441.67.text:
things that are simple
little still lives

443.88.text: that make up the life around you

445.61.text: and are pieces of the puzzle

447.08.text:
in explaining a country
like North Korea.

449.78.text:
But they didn't
allow mobile phones

453.39.text:
Used to be I would
arrive at the country,

455.02.text:
and they would take it away
and lock it up in a box.

459.33.text:
oh foreigners can bring their
phones into the country.

462.86.text:
Not only that, but they opened
a 3G Network, Koryolink.

466.27.text:
And you could do everything
that we do anywhere

467.77.text:
with our phones, right in
the streets of North Korea.

470.47.text:
Suddenly I was sending
pictures to the world,

473.47.text:
tens of thousands of
people following me,

475.44.text:
right from a village
or on the streets.

478.31.text:
And that way, sort
of everything became

480.01.text:
worthy of photography, worthy

I started buying things,

and putting them out on

This was the first one, The

And these were hedgehog

and they became this sort of

So everyday I would

This was a flower festival

and I would post

554.39.text: And I had nothing else to do.

559.99.text:
So I would sit and read

And people would

566.93.text:
And they would have

They call them

but it felt like that, it

578.58.text:
that they were with

They became interested

they became invested in

583.25.text:
And it was a very
different experience

than I'd ever had as

587.19.text:
instead of just publishing

588.89.text:
It was a more

593.73.text:
I was doing all social media
with my phone in North Korea.

596.83.text:
Instagram, I was Tweeting,
I started using Foursquare.

601.30.text:
I rated and did restaurant

608.81.text:
And I opened up

and I saw that it was

And so through Foursquare I
started plotting red flags,

616.25.text:

620.65.text:
Where else in the
world can you feel like

feel like a National

630.13.text:
Besides North Korea,
with a mobile phone.

All I really wanted

was just open a
